Denise Caruso (1956) is a veteran
American
journalist and analyst with more than 15 years experience observing and chronicling the industries of digital technology and interactive media. In the book The Digerati 1, Caruso is listed as “The Idealist.”
She co-founded the non-profit Hybrid Vigor Institute in 2000 to study and practice collaboration in the service of new solutions for complex social and scientific problems.
Caruso is the author of Intervention: Confronting the Real Risks of Genetic Engineering and Life on a Biotech Planet, which won a silver medal at the 2007 Independent Publishers Book Awards for science writing. 2 She also writes the "Re:framing" column for the Sunday Business section of
The New York Times .3
Hybrid Vigor and Beyond
Caruso continues to work on projects both in academia and the private sector to improve critical thinking and decision-making processes, with a special focus on science and technology-related innovations. She is the quintessential idea hamster.
Caruso is an affiliated researcher at the Center for Risk Perception and Communication at Carnegie Mellon University. In 2007, she wrote the Re:framing column, on innovation and creativity, for the Bright Ideas page in the Sunday Business section of The New York Times.
Since founding Hybrid Vigor in 2000, Caruso has garnered financial support for the Institute from the National Science Foundation (NSF), public philanthropies including the Google, Packard, Rockefeller and Surdna Foundations, and several private foundations and individuals. She receives general operating support for her work in critical thinking and decision making from The Whitman Institute.
In addition to her executive duties at Hybrid Vigor, Caruso has developed and served as co-principal investigator on research projects that aim to improve upon traditional methods of risk analysis and decision analysis for innovations.
Public Health Work
She has convened or co-hosted meetings of faculty and investigators for risk-related projects that include world-class natural and social scientists and decision analysts from some of the nation’s most prestigious institutions. Case studies, funded by the NSF, have included the risks of xenotransplantation using genetically modified pigs and the risks of pandemic avian influenza.
Along with several schools of public health and corporate sponsors, Hybrid Vigor co-hosted the cross-sector Pandefense 1.0 meeting in November 2005, which was convened by epidemiologist
Larry Brilliant , M.D. (now executive director of the Google Foundation) and the Global Business Network, with the goal of reducing the probability and effects of an influenza pandemic.
Caruso works closely with the risk expert Baruch Fischhoff, a professor in the Department of Social and Decision Sciences at Carnegie Mellon University, with whom she served as co-investigator on the xenotransplantation project. With Fischhoff and two other colleagues, she was co-author of the article, “Expert Judgments of Pandemic Influenza Risks,” published in the premier issue of the journal Global Public Health''.
She was also co-editor of a Special Report in Harvard Business Review’s May 2006 Forethought section, called “Preparing for a Pandemic.” Additionally, Caruso’s perspectives on risk were presented in an article commissioned by HBR, included in the “HBR List: Breakthrough Ideas for 2005” issue, published in February of that year.
In 2003, Caruso was asked to join the Global Business Network, a worldwide membership organization now owned by the Monitor Group that works to enhance competitive and adaptive capacities in organizations through collaboration, scenario development and strategic planning.
Getting from There to Here
For the five years prior to founding Hybrid Vigor, Caruso wrote the Digital Commerce column for the Monday Information Industries section of The New York Times.
During 1997, she provided on-air commentary and interviews with industry personalities for a MSNBC cable television show about the Internet, called "The Site." She was also founding producer of Spotlight, a successful executive conference on interactive media presented by the International Data Group.
In 1994, Caruso launched Technology & Media Group, an information services company, for
Norman Pearlstine
's Friday Holdings. Pearlstine is the former executive editor of the Wall Street Journal, the former editor-in-chief at Time, Inc., and a former senior advisor at the private equity firm Carlyle Group, now vice president of online media for Bloomberg L.P. Before Technology & Media, Caruso was founding editor of Digital Media, then acclaimed as the seminal newsletter in the emerging new media industry, published by industry pioneer Jonathan Seybold's Seybold Publications.
Prior to launching Digital Media in 1990, Caruso served five years as the anchor columnist for the now-defunct San Francisco Examiner's Sunday technology section. Her career as a technology journalist began in 1984 with two venerable trade publications: InfoWorld, where she served as a reporter and columnist, and in 1985 at Electronics, as West Coast Editor. Caruso's features, essays and analysis have been published in the Wall Street Journal, Columbia Journalism Review, WIRED, I.D. Magazine, The Utne Reader and the San Jose Mercury News; she has also provided occasional commentary for National Public Radio's " Morning Edition" and " All Things Considered."
In March 1999, Caruso accepted a consultancy with the Pew Charitable Trusts, researching standards and practices to increase credibility of information on the Internet. The project was developed into Consumer Reports Web Watch, an ongoing $3.5 million project of Consumers Union, with funding provided by Pew, the Knight Foundation and the Open Society Institute.
Academic, Analyst and Speaker
Beginning in April 1997, she took a year-long position as visiting scholar at Interval Research Corporation in Palo Alto, a think tank and product incubator funded by
Paul Allen
. In spring 1997, Caruso was a visiting lecturer at Stanford University’s Human-Computer Interaction program, in the university's Computer Science department.
A frequent keynote speaker, panelist, participant and moderator at a variety of symposia, seminars and industry events, Caruso has most recently participated in the Science & Media Summit, hosted by the Aspen Science Center; Open Source Conference 2007 hosted by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence; Supernova 2007; the “ Global Threats ... Global Opportunities” conference, hosted by TTI Vanguard; the Fred Friendly Seminar “ Nanotechnology: the Power of Small,” hosted by
John Hockenberry
; The Commonwealth Club of California; the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS); the International Biotech Summit; and the Global Business Network’s 2005 Forum.
As a technology analyst, Caruso presented at many public and private events, including the first-ever Harvard Conference on Internet and Society in 1996 and at the Journalism and Technology conferences at the Nieman Foundation at
Harvard University ; the Newspaper Association of America's annual meeting; the Consumer Electronics Show; the American Center for Design; the American Institute for Graphic Artists; the American Magazine Conference, the Association for Computing Machinery; the Media & Democracy Congress; the Rand Corporation; and the Society of Professional Journalists.
She has also participated in various p]]rograms sponsored by the
American Film Institute
,
Boston College , the Freedom Forum at Columbia University, the Stern School of Business and the Interactive Telecommunications Program at
New York University , the Center for Communication, and the Information Industries Association.
Online First Amendment Pioneer
Caruso is well known as an early advocate of First Amendment rights online, and one of the first analysts to focus on the intersection/collision of technology, commerce and culture. She is a director emerita of the
Electronic Frontier Foundation , and was elected to the Board of Directors of the Independent Media Institute in January 1995, where she continues to serve. She is also a Trustee of the Molecular Sciences Institute, an independent nonprofit research organization based in Berkeley, Calif.
She serves on the advisory boards of Public Knowledge, which advocates for a vibrant “information commons”; London-based SustainAbility.com, the world’s leading business consultancy on corporate responsibility and sustainable development; and the Graduate Program in Design at California College of the Arts.
Caruso holds a BA in English from California Polytechnic State University in San Luis Obispo, Calif., and lives and works in San Francisco.
